key: _gpt-5__What are the conservation benefits of prohibiting spearfishing in marine reserves in the Mediterranean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In the Mediterranean, prohibiting spearfishing in marine reserves has been associated with higher abundances of targeted fish such as European seabass and gilthead seabream after two to seven years.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting spearfishing in Mediterranean marine reserves has been associated with larger sizes of European seabass in protected areas compared to fished areas over similar time frames.
[Statement 3]: Comparisons between spearfished and non-spearfished areas 10–12 years after implementation reported differences in fish densities related to depth and/or fish size.
[Statement 4]: Zones within a Mediterranean marine reserve that prohibited spearfishing saw higher commercial and recreational catches of targeted common dentex than zones allowing spearfishing.
[Statement 5]: Zones within a Mediterranean marine reserve that prohibited spearfishing saw higher commercial and recreational catches of targeted common dentex than areas outside the reserve after one to three years.

[Statement 1]: Prohibiting mobile bottom-towed gears dragged across the seafloor was associated with higher total fish biomass after 15 years.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting mobile bottom-towed gears was associated with larger adult red mullet after 14 years.
[Statement 3]: Prohibiting mobile bottom-towed gears was associated with increased abundances of long-snouted seahorses after one year.
[Statement 4]: Several studies reported no change in overall fish abundance, average fish weight, or species richness/diversity after the prohibition of mobile bottom-towed gears.
[Statement 5]: Haddock recruitment and survival did not increase seven years after the prohibition of mobile bottom-towed gears.
[Statement 6]: Recruitment increased for young red mullet 14 years after the prohibition of mobile bottom-towed gears.
[Statement 7]: Prohibiting all bottom gears, both mobile and static, was associated with higher numbers of larger and older cod after 15 years.
[Statement 8]: Prohibiting all bottom gears was associated with improved cod growth after 5 to 15 years.
[Statement 9]: After prohibiting all bottom gears, fish densities showed mixed responses that varied by species, group, and environmental factors.
[Statement 10]: In some cases, after prohibiting all bottom gears, fish densities showed no differences after 2 to 7 years.

key: _gpt-5__What are the effects on marine fish populations of prohibiting different types of bottom fishing gear?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Effort controls, such as limiting the number of fishing days, are alternatives to setting catch quotas.
[Statement 2]: In one Mediterranean study, limiting the number of fishing days was followed by a higher biomass of thornback and brown rays.
[Statement 3]: Restricting fishing activity by vessel size or engine power is an alternative for controlling fishing mortality.
[Statement 4]: Excluding higher-power vessels for part of each year was followed by a higher abundance of commercially targeted fish.
[Statement 5]: The effects of excluding higher-power vessels from fishing varied by fish size groups.
[Statement 6]: Limiting the number of fishers or vessels via permits or licences is a proposed alternative to catch quotas.
[Statement 7]: No direct evaluation was found for the effect of limiting the number of fishers or vessels.
[Statement 8]: Limits on the number or length of static nets have been proposed as alternatives to catch quotas.
[Statement 9]: Limits on the number of traps or pots per vessel have been proposed as alternatives to catch quotas.
[Statement 10]: Spatial–temporal measures, such as temporary closures, are alternatives for controlling fishing mortality.
[Statement 11]: The outcomes of using temporary closures to control fishing mortality have been mixed.
[Statement 12]: Following temporary closures, cod biomass, survival, and length composition did not increase compared to fished areas.
[Statement 13]: Tagged cod spent about a third of their time inside a seasonal spawning closure.
[Statement 14]: Real-time closures reduced the annual amount of cod that was caught.
[Statement 15]: Some targeted fisheries saw increased catch rates after temporary closures ended.
[Statement 16]: Temporary closures also affected non-fish taxa, leading to reduced lethal turtle strandings.
[Statement 17]: Fishery shutdowns occurred when turtle bycatch limits were reached.
[Statement 18]: For benthic invertebrates, temporarily closing or reopening areas produced varied changes in abundance and condition.
[Statement 19]: Long-term closures showed mixed responses for fish populations.
[Statement 20]: Long-term closures combined with gear-limited areas led to reductions in unwanted cod catch.
[Statement 21]: Long-term closures combined with gear-limited areas reduced the overall fishing effort for sandeel.
[Statement 22]: Size-based regulations, including minimum landing sizes, are alternatives for controlling fishing mortality.
[Statement 23]: Evidence on the effect of minimum landing sizes on fish recruitment and discards was mixed.
[Statement 24]: In one case, minimum landing sizes led to some reductions in catches of the youngest fish.
[Statement 25]: In another case, immature fish persisted in landings despite minimum landing sizes being in place.
[Statement 26]: There was a lack of direct evaluations for the effect of size limits on recreationally caught invertebrate species.
[Statement 27]: Gear selectivity modifications offer alternatives to reduce the mortality of non-target or undersized fish.
[Statement 28]: Fitting trawl nets with escape panels, windows, and size-sorting grids can reduce unwanted catches.
[Statement 29]: Using escape panels, windows, and size-sorting grids in trawl nets improved size-selectivity in multiple studies.

key: _gpt-5__What are some alternatives to setting catch quotas for controlling fishing mortality?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Reducing air exposure before release did not increase the survival of small-spotted catshark caught by trawling.
[Statement 2]: Shorter air exposure improved the physical condition and reduced injury of discarded chum salmon.
[Statement 3]: Minimal air exposure and handling improved the post-release behaviour of reef fish.
[Statement 4]: Releasing captured fish alive resulted in the majority (76–92%) of several species surviving for at least 1 hour to 5 days.
[Statement 5]: Less than half of smooth skate survived after being released alive.
[Statement 6]: Survival of released fish was reduced by injuries related to hooking and capture depth.
[Statement 7]: Survival of released fish was reduced by longer tow durations.
[Statement 8]: Nearly all yelloweye rockfish survived 4 days post-release.
[Statement 9]: Canary rockfish survival decreased with increasing capture depth.
[Statement 10]: Devilrays survived when brailed aboard from purse seines but did not survive when brought aboard entangled.
[Statement 11]: Establishing handling and release protocols with minimal handling and air exposure led to faster returns to the reef or seabed for reef fish.
[Statement 12]: Tracked whale sharks released using an enhanced purse-seine protocol survived at least 21 days with normal movements.
[Statement 13]: Using different hook types reduced hook injuries that are associated with higher post-release mortality.
[Statement 14]: Using different hook types reduced capture mortality for some unwanted sharks, rays, and some non-target billfish.
[Statement 15]: Other studies found no reduction in mortality from using different hook types.
[Statement 16]: Some studies reported reduced deep-hooking without a corresponding reduction in mortality.
[Statement 17]: Modifying longline configuration produced mixed survival outcomes for unwanted sharks.
[Statement 18]: One global review reported higher survival for two of three shark species on nylon hook attachments and lower survival for one species.
[Statement 19]: One field study found reduced survival for unwanted sharks on nylon hook attachments compared to wire attachments.
[Statement 20]: Using hook-and-line gear instead of other commercial gear produced greater fish vitality, which is an indicator of post-release survival.

key: _gpt-5__What does the evidence say about how different fishing practices affect the survival of fish after capture and release?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies report varied effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance across multiple ocean basins.
[Statement 2]: In the Mediterranean Sea, site comparisons reported no increase in biomass for some targeted species 2–13 years after a commercial fishing closure compared to a fished area.
[Statement 3]: Other studies in the Mediterranean Sea and additional basins recorded higher abundances for subsets of species, such as some commercially targeted and non-targeted groups.
[Statement 4]: In the Indian Ocean and Gulf of Mexico, some site comparison studies found higher abundances for parts of the fish community in areas closed to fishing.
[Statement 5]: Other site comparison studies in the Indian Ocean and Gulf of Mexico reported mixed outcomes across fish species and groups.
[Statement 6]: In the South Atlantic Ocean, one study found no change in fish species composition in protected areas relative to fished areas.
[Statement 7]: Abundance-focused comparisons spanning the South Atlantic Ocean and other basins showed responses ranging from higher abundances in some commercially exploited species to mixed effects depending on exploitation history.
[Statement 8]: In the Tasman Sea, a before-and-after study in an estuary found lower abundances for most species two years after a commercial fishing closure.
[Statement 9]: Another study in a Tasman Sea reserve zone closed to commercial trapping reported abundance patterns that varied over a decade and among fish groups.
[Statement 10]: In the South China Sea, overall fish density in the wider region increased within five years after reserves limiting commercial fishing were created.
[Statement 11]: The creation of reserves limiting commercial fishing in the South China Sea was accompanied by shifts in fish assemblage composition.
[Statement 12]: Syntheses and multi-region studies of fully non-fished marine protected areas frequently found higher total fish abundance and biomass compared to fished or partially fished areas.
[Statement 13]: Multi-region studies of fully non-fished marine protected areas frequently found higher abundances of many targeted and non-targeted species compared to fished or partially fished areas.
[Statement 14]: Several studies of marine protected areas reported similar or species-dependent effects on fish abundance when comparing non-fished areas to fished areas.
[Statement 15]: The variability in the effects of marine protected areas is linked to species group, trophic position, fish size, depth, and habitat.
[Statement 16]: The variability in the effects of marine protected areas is linked to the protected area's age and size.

key: _gpt-5__How do the effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance vary across different ocean basins?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Establishing move-on rules that trigger temporary closures when catch thresholds are reached was associated with lower overall cod discards.
[Statement 2]: Using technology to communicate near real-time catch information to fishers was reported to reduce unwanted catch or discards.
[Statement 3]: Setting catch limits or quotas for non-targeted commercial species reduced unwanted catch.
[Statement 4]: Catch limits reduced unwanted halibut, whereas a previous individual transferable quota system did not.
[Statement 5]: Implementing a combination of long-term fishery closures and areas limited to specific gears reduced unwanted catch of cod.
[Statement 6]: Implementing a combination of prohibiting non-selective gear types and long-term closures reduced unwanted catch of cod.

key: _gpt-5__What are the most effective non-gear-modification strategies for reducing unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Protecting spawning fish from capture is a management action to protect the reproductive capacity of fish populations.
[Statement 2]: Protecting spawning fish can be done through seasonal or permanent closures of spawning or nursery areas.
[Statement 3]: Studies reported no increase in Atlantic cod spawning stock biomass or survival nine years after a seasonal closure.
[Statement 4]: Tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside a seasonally closed spawning area.
[Statement 5]: Young school sharks used closed nursery areas extensively.
[Statement 6]: Establishing temporary fishery closures is a management action to protect fish populations.
[Statement 7]: One study found no increase in cod spawning stock biomass, survival, or length composition over nine years of temporary fishery closures.
[Statement 8]: Tagged cod spent nearly a third of their time inside a closed spawning area during the implementation of a temporary closure.
[Statement 9]: Real-time area closures reduced the annual catch of cod, including both retained and discarded fish.
[Statement 10]: Ceasing or prohibiting all fishing in marine protected areas, also known as no-take zones, is a management action.
[Statement 11]: Multiple studies found higher abundances of fish and larger fish in marine protected areas compared to fished areas.
[Statement 12]: One study found more eggs of four commercially targeted species inside a non-fished reserve than outside the reserve.
[Statement 13]: Setting minimum landing sizes for commercially fished species is a management action.
[Statement 14]: One review reported increased swordfish recruitment in one of five fisheries after recommended minimum sizes and catch limits were implemented.
[Statement 15]: A replicated study reported most fish landed were immature despite minimum size regulations.
[Statement 16]: Other studies showed that setting minimum landing sizes had mixed effects on unwanted catch.
[Statement 17]: Setting maximum landing sizes for commercially fished species is a management action.
[Statement 18]: No studies currently evaluate the effects of setting maximum landing sizes for commercially fished species.
[Statement 19]: Releasing fish that are carrying eggs or live young is a management action.
[Statement 20]: No studies currently evaluate the effects of releasing fish that are carrying eggs or live young.
[Statement 21]: Releasing protected or species of concern alive after capture is a management action.
[Statement 22]: Replicated studies reported a majority short-term survival rate of 76–92% in several species released after capture.
[Statement 23]: The survival of released fish is influenced by depth-related injuries and tow duration.
[Statement 24]: Some species experienced lower survival or gear-related mortality after being released.

key: _gpt-5__What management actions are available to specifically protect the reproductive capacity of fish populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Three studies on involving fishers and stakeholders in co-management reported mixed outcomes.
[Statement 2]: One before-and-after study in the Indian Ocean found increased overall fish abundance nine years after co-management implementation.
[Statement 3]: In a study in the Indian Ocean, fish abundance responses to co-management implementation varied among species groups.
[Statement 4]: In the Pacific (Tonga), five years after a new co-management system was established, there was no decrease in overall fishing effort.
[Statement 5]: In the Pacific (Tonga), five years after a new co-management system was established, there was no increase in total fish catch rates.
[Statement 6]: In a study in the Pacific (Tonga), catch rates decreased for half of six species groups five years after a new co-management system was established.
[Statement 7]: In the South China Sea (Vietnam), illegal fishing using destructive gears decreased after co-management was established.
[Statement 8]: Evidence gaps were reported for several related stakeholder-involvement actions.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found that evaluated engaging fishers in scientific data collection on marine fish populations.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found that evaluated involving stakeholders in the allocation of harvest rights on marine fish populations.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found that evaluated including fishers in MPA management fora on marine fish populations.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found that evaluated involving fishers in designing or trialling new selective gear on marine fish populations.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found that evaluated promoting knowledge exchange between fishers to improve good practice on marine fish populations.
[Statement 14]: No studies were found that evaluated engaging stakeholders when designating MPAs on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations.

key: _gpt-5__What is the state of evidence for the effectiveness of involving fishers and other stakeholders in marine conservation management?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Using technology to share near real-time catch information with fishers was associated with reductions in unwanted catch or discards in the North Pacific and North Atlantic Oceans.
[Statement 2]: Establishing move-on rules that delay or relocate fishing when mammals are encountered, combined with releasing trapped animals, resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed in the Great Australian Bight.
[Statement 3]: Establishing temporary fishery closures was associated with fewer lethal strandings of loggerhead and Kemp’s ridley turtles during seasonal shrimp trawl closures in the USA.
[Statement 4]: Swordfish longline fisheries were closed when annual turtle bycatch limits were reached, which limited further bycatch for the remainder of those years.
[Statement 5]: For the operational approach of selectively avoiding unwanted fish based on temperature distribution, the evidence base was reported as absent.
[Statement 6]: For the operational approach of using remote tools to detect mammals and altering vessel course or speed, the evidence base was reported as absent.
[Statement 7]: For the operational approach of using human observers onboard vessels to monitor catches and discards, the evidence base was reported as absent.

key: _gpt-5__What are the most effective operational tactics for fishers to reduce unwanted catch without modifying the main structure of their nets or lines?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Fishing activity can be restricted within marine protected areas.
[Statement 2]: Zonation systems can be implemented to control human activity with different levels of fishing restriction.
[Statement 3]: Zonation systems can include no-take and partially fished zones.
[Statement 4]: Temporary or seasonal fishery closures can be established.
[Statement 5]: Targeted, trigger-based move-on rules can be established for when catch or unwanted catch thresholds are reached.
[Statement 6]: Certain categories of fishing, such as recreational fishing or harvesting, can be limited or prohibited.
[Statement 7]: Size limits can be set for recreational species.
[Statement 8]: Limits can be set on catches, including quotas for non-target catch and species-specific catch shares.
[Statement 9]: Overall catch limits by fishery or fleet can be set.
[Statement 10]: Specific gear types or classes of gear, such as all towed or mobile gears in a marine protected area, can be prohibited.
[Statement 11]: Gear and vessel restrictions can be enforced.
[Statement 12]: Fishing capacity or effort can be limited by capping vessel numbers.
[Statement 13]: Fishing capacity or effort can be limited by restricting permits and licences.
[Statement 14]: Fishing can be restricted by vessel size or engine power.
[Statement 15]: The selectivity of fishing gear can be modified to reduce unwanted catch.
[Statement 16]: Unwanted catch can be reduced by setting minimum or maximum landing sizes.
[Statement 17]: Unwanted catch can be reduced by increasing the mesh size of pots and traps.
[Statement 18]: Unwanted catch can be reduced by using square-mesh trawl codends.
[Statement 19]: Trawls can be fitted with escape panels, windows, and size-sorting grids to reduce unwanted catch.
[Statement 20]: Monitoring and compliance can be strengthened using onboard human observers and onboard CCTV.
[Statement 21]: Patrol boats can be used to strengthen monitoring and compliance.
[Statement 22]: Fishing permit, licence, or charter schemes can be used to strengthen monitoring and compliance.

key: _gpt-5__What actions are available within a marine protected area to manage fishing activity without imposing a complete ban on all fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A site comparison in South Africa reported that prohibiting offshore line fishing and other boat-based fishing in a marine protected area zone was associated with higher abundance of four line-exploited fish species.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting offshore line fishing and other boat-based fishing in a South African marine protected area zone was associated with larger sizes of four line-exploited fish species compared to zones where fishing was permitted.
[Statement 3]: Modifying longline configuration showed mixed effects on fish populations and unwanted catch.
[Statement 4]: Increasing lead weight on longlines reduced unwanted shark and ray catches in some fisheries or reviews.
[Statement 5]: Using nylon instead of wire on longlines reduced unwanted shark and ray catches in some fisheries or reviews.
[Statement 6]: One study found that modifying longline configuration caused no reduction in the catch of undersized haddock.
[Statement 7]: A review reported that the survival of unwanted sharks and rays at retrieval was higher on nylon lines than on wire lines for some species.
[Statement 8]: A field study found that the survival of unwanted sharks and rays at retrieval was reduced on nylon lines versus wire lines.
[Statement 9]: Changing bait type often reduced unwanted catches of undersized haddock, Atlantic cod, and other non-target fish in several replicated studies.
[Statement 10]: In some studies, changing bait type had no effect on the reduction of pelagic stingray or overall unwanted fish catches.
[Statement 11]: Two global reviews found that changing bait type had no effect on unwanted shark and ray catches.
[Statement 12]: Using different bait did not reduce hooking injuries or increase the survival of undersized snapper or sharks and rays.
[Statement 13]: One study reported that using a different bait increased size-selectivity for Greenland halibut.
[Statement 14]: Replacing J-hooks with circle hooks generally reduced sea turtle bycatch in multiple studies and a review.
[Statement 15]: Replacing J-hooks with circle hooks resulted in fewer deep or swallowed hooks for sea turtles.
[Statement 16]: One review found that using circle hooks instead of J-hooks led to fewer turtle deaths in most of the assessed fisheries.
[Statement 17]: The effects of replacing J-hooks with circle hooks on sea turtle bycatch varied among fisheries and with bait type.
[Statement 18]: Evidence for mitigating seabird bycatch on longlines is variable.
[Statement 19]: One Australian study found lower seabird bycatch on longlines with the use of bait throwers.
[Statement 20]: A North Pacific trial recorded higher seabird bycatch on longlines with a line shooter.
[Statement 21]: A Norwegian trial found that a line shooter had no effect on seabird bycatch.
[Statement 22]: No intervention-based evidence was found for the effectiveness of high-visibility longlines or water cannons in mitigating seabird bycatch.
[Statement 23]: Using non-ringed circle hooks in a Mediterranean swordfish longline fishery reduced loggerhead turtle catch compared to using ringed hooks.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented effects of different restrictions on line fishing, such as prohibitions or gear modifications, on fish populations and unwanted catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Fitting size-sorting escape grids (rigid or flexible) to prawn or shrimp trawl nets can reduce unwanted fish and total unwanted catch.
[Statement 2]: Installing size-sorting mesh funnels or sieve nets in shrimp trawls has reduced catches of unwanted fish.
[Statement 3]: Adding large, supported escape openings such as Fisheyes, Bigeyes, or radial escape sections to trawl nets can reduce overall unwanted fish, immature red snapper, and total unwanted catch.
[Statement 4]: The addition of large, supported escape openings to trawl nets has also been shown to reduce unwanted shark catch.
[Statement 5]: Combining square-mesh escape panels or windows with size-sorting grids in trawl nets has reduced unwanted fish, sharks and rays, and total discards.
[Statement 6]: Modifying the design or attachments of shrimp or prawn W-trawl nets caught less non-commercial unwanted crustacean bycatch than a traditional trawl.
[Statement 7]: Using topless or coverless trawls has reduced discards or unwanted catches of some commercial species.
[Statement 8]: Using different designs or configurations of size-sorting escape grids or systems can reduce unwanted catches or improve size-selectivity, depending on species and conditions.
[Statement 9]: Rotating the orientation of diamond-mesh in codends by 90 degrees improved size-selection for several round-bodied fish species.
[Statement 10]: Modifying the configuration (position, size, or mesh size) of mesh escape panels or windows can reduce unwanted catches of some species or improve size-selectivity.
[Statement 11]: Decreasing the circumference or diameter of the codend has been shown in some studies to reduce discarded fish catches.
[Statement 12]: Decreasing the circumference or diameter of the codend has been shown in some studies to improve size-selectivity for multiple species.

key: _gpt-5__In prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries, what gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Gear modifications are used to reduce unwanted fish catch in prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries.
[Statement 2]: Fitting size-sorting mesh funnels, also known as sieve nets, to shrimp trawls is a gear modification used to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 3]: Installing size-sorting escape grids, which can be rigid or flexible, in prawn and shrimp trawl nets is a gear modification used to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 4]: Adding large, supported escape openings such as Fisheyes, Bigeyes, or radial escape sections to trawl nets is a gear modification used to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 5]: Combining square-mesh escape panels or windows with size-sorting grids in trawl nets is a gear modification used to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 6]: Using trawl nets with square-mesh escape panels and a square-mesh codend instead of a diamond-mesh codend is a gear modification used to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 7]: Using topless or coverless trawls is a gear modification used to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 8]: Varying the design or configuration of size-sorting escape grid systems can improve the escape of unwanted fish.
[Statement 9]: Modifying the configuration, including the position, size, or mesh size, of mesh escape panels or windows in trawl nets can reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 10]: Decreasing the circumference or diameter of the trawl codend is a gear modification used to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 11]: Rotating the orientation of diamond mesh by 90° in trawl codends is a gear modification used to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 12]: Fitting moving "stimulator" devices to trawl nets can encourage fish escape responses.

key: _gpt-5__What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish in commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Replicated, controlled studies report that various trawl-gear design changes improved size‑selectivity for unwanted fish and annular seabream in the North Sea and Mediterranean.
[Statement 2]: Examples of trawl-gear design changes include modifications to extension length, strengthening bag, weaving method, codend layers, and overall design.
[Statement 3]: Alternative designs or configurations of size‑sorting escape grids in trawls improved size‑selectivity for unwanted redfish, Greenland halibut, and target hake in some cases.
[Statement 4]: Other studies on size‑sorting escape grids in trawls showed species‑specific outcomes or no improvement in size-selectivity.
[Statement 5]: Decreasing trawl codend circumference or diameter improved size‑selectivity for haddock, Atlantic cod, whiting, European hake, and red mullet.
[Statement 6]: The effects of decreasing trawl codend circumference or diameter varied among species and could be reduced for one species.
[Statement 7]: In encircling nets, transparent netting panels improved size‑selectivity for one of four commercial fish species tested.
[Statement 8]: Modified traps or pots with square‑mesh escape windows or larger mesh improved size‑selectivity for Atlantic cod, black sea bass, and most species tested.
[Statement 9]: One study found that modified traps or pots with square‑mesh escape windows or larger mesh had no effect on size-selectivity for panga.
[Statement 10]: Adding moving stimulator devices alongside square‑mesh escape panels improved cod size‑selectivity for one of three device types in the Baltic Sea.
[Statement 11]: Some gear modifications showed no improvement in size-selectivity.
[Statement 12]: Reducing the main trawl body size did not improve the size‑selection of cod and haddock.
[Statement 13]: LED lights on a size‑sorting grid did not improve size‑selectivity for long rough dab, Atlantic cod, haddock, and redfish.

key: _gpt-5__What is the evidence for gear modifications improving the size-selectivity of commercial fishing gear?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Allowing only small-scale traditional fishing in a marine protected area zone for three years was associated with higher overall commercial catch rates for five of seven species compared to openly fished areas.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting all fishing with limited exceptions in marine protected areas produced lower total fish species richness in some areas compared to unprotected sites.
[Statement 3]: When only bait fishing was allowed in marine protected areas, there was similar biomass and lower total fish density compared to unprotected sites.
[Statement 4]: Prohibiting all fishing with limited exceptions in marine protected areas produced similar abundance for several rockfish species and lingcod relative to fished sites.
[Statement 5]: Prohibiting all fishing with limited exceptions in marine protected areas led to increased cod survival inside the protected area.
[Statement 6]: Prohibiting all fishing with limited exceptions in marine protected areas resulted in frequent, prolonged use of protected habitats by some shark species, which reduced the likelihood of fishing mortality for those sharks.
[Statement 7]: Closing areas to all non-towed (static) fishing gears was associated with higher overall shark abundance when sampled with longlines compared to areas permitting commercial gillnets.
[Statement 8]: Closing areas to all non-towed (static) fishing gears was not associated with higher overall shark abundance when sampled with gillnets.
[Statement 9]: Closing areas to all non-towed (static) fishing gears was associated with greater length for two of five shark species or groups compared to areas permitting commercial gillnets.
[Statement 10]: Prohibiting commercial fishing was associated with different benthic invertebrate community composition relative to fished areas.
[Statement 11]: In one case, prohibiting commercial fishing caused no change in overall invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 12]: In two cases, there was greater overall invertebrate abundance in areas closed to commercial fishing.
[Statement 13]: In one area closed to commercial fishing, invertebrate biomass was higher, while in another area it was similar to fished areas.
[Statement 14]: There was no difference in lobster abundance after up to two years in areas where commercial fishing was prohibited.
[Statement 15]: Invertebrates showed greater biological production in areas where trawling and dredging had been excluded for 28 years.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented ecological outcomes of managing small-scale traditional fisheries, either through prohibition or by making them the only permitted fishing type?
